M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action arising from Defendant Michael Richards' breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as codified in M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, and recognized under Massachusetts common law.

M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under M.G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000, and the Somerville District Court has jurisdiction over civil matters arising in this county.

*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 594 (195.proposition: Defendant’s actions, or lack thereof, represent a clear violation of the implied duties of a landlord under Massachusetts law, as recognized in *Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 594 (1950) and related authorities.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 594 (195.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dartmouth v. Silva deals exclusively with the procedural doctrine of res judicata and the effect of judgments entered after sustaining demurrers; it does not address landlord-tenant law, implied duties of a landlord, or any substantive obligations of landlords under Massachusetts law. Because the case is about claim preclusion and not about landlord duties, it cannot be cited as authority for a violation of implied landlord duties.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 594 (195.relevant_excerpt: "The defence of res judicata ordinarily must rest upon the fact that a judgment upon the merits had been entered in the former litigation... The general rule in this Commonwealth is that a judgment following the sustaining of a demurrer is not a bar to a second action for the same cause of action. It has been stated that 'The reason for the rule is that such a judgment commonly is based not on the merits but upon the insufficiency of the statement of the cause of action.'"
